IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 14873 S0926-860X(14)00399-8 10.1016/j.apcata.2014.06.013 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 The activity of TiO2, MnO x , SnO x , Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts for CB combustion, gas composition: 2500mg/m3 CB, 20% O2, N2 balance; GHSV=20,000h−1. Fig. 2 The stabilities of Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts for CB combustion at different temperatures; (a) 175°C; (b) 200°C; (c) 225°C; (d) 250°C; (e) 300°C; gas composition: 2500mg/m3 CB, 20% O2, N2 balance; GHSV=20,000h−1. Fig. 3 The stabilities of Mn–Ti and X–Mn–Ti (X=Ce, La, Ru, Sn) catalysts for CB combustion at 175°C; gas composition: 2500mg/m3 CB, 20% O2, N2 balance; GHSV=20,000h−1. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts before and after CB oxidation: used Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti represent catalysts reacted at 175°C for 100h. Fig. 5 Raman spectra of Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts before and after CB oxidation. Fig. 6 SAED patterns of TiO2 (A) Mn–Ti (B) and Sn–Mn–Ti (C) catalysts. Fig. 7 Mn 2p (A), O 1s (B), Sn 3d (C) and Cl 2p (D) XPS spectra of the fresh and used catalysts: a, fresh Mn–Ti; b, used Mn–Ti; c, fresh Sn–Mn–Ti; d, used Sn–Mn–Ti. Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles of Mn–Ti (A) and Sn–Mn–Ti (B) catalysts: fresh represents fresh catalysts; 175°C, 225°C, 250°C and 300°C represent the catalysts reacted at corresponding temperatures for 100h, respectively, and denoted as Mn–Ti(X) or Sn–Mn–Ti(X) in the text, i.e., Mn–Ti(175°C). Table 1 Physical properties and XPS data of fresh and used catalysts. Catalysts Surface area (m2/g) a Pore volume (×10−2 cm3/g) Average pore size (nm) Mn/Mn+Ti b Sn/Sn +Mn+Ti b Mn (at.%) O (at.%) Sn (at.%) Mn4+ Mn3+ Mn2+ Olatt Oads Owat Sn4+ Sn2+ Fresh Mn–Ti 261 22.98 3.52 18.8 (25) – 27.1 50.3 22.6 59.9 33.5 6.6 – – Used Mn–Ti 245 21.89 3.58 – – 11.7 48.5 39.8 79.4 16.7 3.9 – – Fresh Sn–Mn–Ti 236 16.64 2.82 10.7 (22.3) 18.6 (9.1) 11.7 41.6 45.7 83.3 11.7 5 85.5 14.5 Used Sn–Mn–Ti 216 16.50 3.05 – – 10 45.5 44.5 90.1 8.1 1.8 75.2 24.8 a The specific surface area is calculated using the BET model. b The data inside and outside the brackets correspond to the composition of Mn or Sn in the preparation and the value estimated by XPS analysis, respectively. SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts with high resistance to chlorine poisoning for low-temperature chlorobenzene oxidation Jingwei Li Pei Zhao Shantang Liu ⁎ Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430074, China Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Process of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Pharmacy, Wuhan Institute of Technology Wuhan 430074 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.:+86 27 87195001; fax: +86 27 87195001. Graphical abstract In this study, MnO x –TiO2 and SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts were prepared using a homogeneous precipitation method and were investigated for the catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene (CB), which was used as a model compound of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs). The catalytic activity tests revealed that both catalysts exhibited an outstanding activity in catalytic degradation of CB, with 90% conversion occurring below 180°C. A significantly higher stability was observed for the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst compared with Mn–Ti samples, revealing that the stability of Mn–Ti catalysts for the oxidation of chlorobenzene could be remarkably improved via the introduction of Sn. The obtained catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, N2 physisorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron (XPS) and hydrogen temperature-programed reduction (H2-TPR). Characterization of the catalysts indicated that the enhanced catalytic stability of the SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts was related to the lower average energy required to desorb Cl species and to the absence of MnO x Cl y on the active sites during the reaction, which remarkably improved the thermal stability of catalyst. Hence, SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts are a potential material for the abatement of CVOCs. Keywords MnO x –TiO2 Sn Chlorine removal Chlorobenzene Catalytic combustion 1 Introduction Catalytic combustion is recognized as an effective technology for reducing CVOCs emissions from waste gases because of its high removal efficiency and good selectivity. Among the catalysts employed in the catalytic oxidation of CVOCs, titania-supported vanadium oxide has been successfully applied in industrial processes due to its relatively low cost and high stability. Anatase TiO2, as the support, has many advantages, such as high specific surface area, excellent dispersing effect for active components, good thermal and anticorrosive properties and so on [1–3]. Nevertheless, the active phase VO x is not sufficiently desirable (the operating temperature is in the range of 300–450°C). Moreover, VO x is highly toxic to humans and animals. Therefore, developing other highly active catalysts as alternatives to vanadium oxide that are not only environmentally friendly but also resistant to catalytic deactivation is of importance. Manganese oxides, as a type of environmental-friendly material, have attracted continuous attention because of their excellent catalytic performance and widespread applications, such as the catalytic combustion of toluene, benzene and ethyl acetate [4–8]; the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 [9–13]; and CO oxidation or hydrogenation [14–16]. Therefore, manganese oxides have been widely recognized as one of the most efficient transition-metal oxide catalysts for catalytic disposal of pollutants and have great potential as an alternative to VO x in the abatement of CVOCs [17,18]. However, these oxides are susceptible to catalytic deactivation due to the strong adsorption of dissociative Cl species, which are mainly generated from the combustion processes. For this reason, some researchers have hypothesized that manganese oxides could only be applied in a Cl-free atmosphere [19]. Improving resistance of these catalysts to deactivation will extend the application range of manganese oxides in industry. However, to the best of our knowledge, most researchers have focused more attention on the catalytic performance, with the stability test as a supplementary analysis, and only a few exclusive studies are available with respect to improving the stability of the catalysts. In this study, we tried to introduce foreign elements to the host MnO x –TiO2 catalyst for enhancing its resistance to chlorine poisoning. As far as we know, some elements, such as La, Ce, Ru and Sn, have special effects when added to catalyst as additives. For example, the addition of La can improve the thermal stability of catalysts [20]; CeO2 has been widely investigated due to its high oxygen storage capacity and facile Ce4+/Ce3+ redox cycle [21]; the oxides of Ru and Sn are not so susceptible to Cl2 or HCl and can exist at the atmosphere of Cl2 or HCl for a relative long time [22]. We introduced the above mentioned elements to MnO x –TiO2 catalyst and found that the addition of Sn was effective for our purpose. Subsequently, a series of SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 mixed-oxide catalysts with different Sn content were synthesized using a homogeneous precipitation method to investigate the effect of Sn on the catalytic stability of MnO x –TiO2 catalysts for CB combustion. Additionally, a possible reason for the good stability of SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalyst was discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation In this study, SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts were prepared using a homogeneous precipitation method, as follows: an aqueous solution containing SnCl2·2H2O (SCRC, 98.0%), Mn(NO3)2 (50wt.% solution), Ti(SO4)2 (SCRC, 96.0%), urea (SCRC, 99.0%) and polyethylene glycol (in the solution, Mn/Ti=1:3, Sn/(Mn+Ti)=1:10, molar ratio) was gradually heated to 90°C and maintained at this temperature for 10h with vigorous stirring. After filtering and washing several times with ultrapure water, the obtained sample was dried at 110°C for 12h and then calcined at 400°C for 5h in air. The same method was employed to prepare MnO x –TiO2 and TiO2 catalyst (without the addition of SnCl2·2H2O or Mn(NO3)2). The composition of the reaction solution and calcination temperature were the same as those in the aforementioned procedure. The synthesized MnO x –TiO2 and SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts are denoted as Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The phase structures of the catalysts were analyzed using an X’Pert PW3050/60 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 40mA). Raman spectra were recorded on a laser confocal Raman miscroscope (DXR, American Thermo Electron) operated at a wavelength of 532nm. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen-adsorption apparatus. The specific surface areas of samples were measured using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the pore volumes and pore size distributions were determined using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. TEM images were acquired using a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope. The samples were ground in ethanol using a mortar and mounted onto Cu grids coated with a holey carbon film without any metal coating. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with Al Kα X-rays radiation (hυ =1253.6eV) (XPS: VG Multilab 2000) was used to analyze the surface atomic states of the catalysts. The TPR runs were conducted with a linear heating rate (10°C/min) in a flow of 10% H2 in argon at a flow rate of 40mL/min. The hydrogen consumption was measured quantitatively by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Catalytic activity test Catalytic combustion reactions were performed at atmospheric pressure in a continuous flow micro-reactor, which was made of a quartz tube with an 8mm in inner diameter, with 0.2g of catalyst packed in the center of the reactor. CB was introduced into the reactor by a carrier gas of N2 through a saturator maintained at 0°C, and then it was mixed with N2 and O2 in a mixing drum. The feed flow through the reactor was set with a CB concentration of 2500mg/m3 and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20,000h−1. The reaction temperature was measured and controlled with a thermocouple located at the thermal spot of the reactor. The effluent gases were analyzed at a given temperature using an online gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) for the quantitative analysis of CB. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity for CB oxidation The activities of TiO2, MnO x , SnO x , Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti are shown in Fig. 1 . Compared to the support TiO2 and additive SnO x , which exhibit no significant oxidation of CB at temperatures up to 250°C, the Mn–Ti catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity, and the temperatures required for the conversion of 50% and 90% of CB (T50% and T90%) were 147°C and 177°C, respectively. In the case of Sn–Mn–Ti, when the content of Sn was not greater than 10% (Sn/Mn+Ti=10%, molar ratio), the activity was almost identical to that of the Mn–Ti catalyst, indicating that a small amount of Sn did not affect the activity of Mn–Ti catalyst. With further Sn addition, the activity of the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst decreased significantly. Although MnO x performed best for CB combustion, it deactivated quickly during the activity test. The activity tests revealed that Mn is the active component in the catalysts: Sn acts as an additive, and the small amount of Sn minimally affects the activity of the catalyst. Although TiO2, as a support, exhibits fairly low activity, it plays an important role in the dispersion of Mn or Sn. 3.2 Stability study of catalysts The stability of catalysts is a very important factor to consider for practical applications. Fig. 2 shows the stabilities of the Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts that were continuously reacted for 100h at different temperatures. As shown in this figure, both catalysts deactivate to some extent at low temperatures (less than 225°C). The activity of the Mn–Ti catalyst is not stable until 300°C, whereas for Sn–Mn–Ti, the temperature required for stable activity is 225°C, which is much lower than that of other manganese-containing catalysts [20,23–27], noble metal catalysts [28] and other catalysts [29]. Moreover, compared with Mn–Ti catalyst, the deactivation rate of Sn–Mn–Ti is slower, and the final stable activity is higher at temperatures below 300°C. These facts indicate that the addition of Sn can clearly enhance the stability of the Mn–Ti catalyst. To enhance the catalyst's resistance to chlorine poisoning, we also attempted to introduce some other additives (the rare earth element Ce and La and the noble metal Ru) to the Mn–Ti catalyst. Fig. 3 presents the stabilities of the Mn–Ti and X–Mn–Ti (X=Ce, La, Ru and Sn; X/Mn+Ti=10%, molar ratio) catalysts for the combustion of CB at 175°C. As shown, not every additive was capable of improving the resistance of the Mn–Ti catalyst to chlorine poisoning (i.e., Ce). On the other hand, the addition of La did not significantly improve the stability of the Mn–Ti catalyst, and a substantial decrease in CB conversion was observed within 30h. For the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst, although deactivation was still observed after 25h, it's clear that the stability of the Mn–Ti catalyst could be substantially improved by the addition of Sn. A series of characterizations were subsequently conducted to investigate the effect of Sn. 3.3 Catalyst characterization The wide-angle XRD patterns of the fresh and used catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . Pure TiO2 and the fresh Mn–Ti catalysts display the anatase phase, which is characterized by peaks at approximately 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.1°, 54.8°, 62.5°, 69.7° and 74.9°, and no signals corresponding to MnO x species appear for the Mn–Ti catalyst. Compared to TiO2, the diffraction peaks of the fresh Mn–Ti shift to higher Bragg angles, from 25.3° to 25.6°, indicating that manganese species can enter the anatase TiO2 lattice to form MnTiO x solid solutions [20]. The ionic radii of Ti4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+ are 0.068, 0.066 and 0.08nm, respectively, and the ions with similar valences and radii could substitute for each other and form solid solutions more easily. In the case of fresh Sn–Mn–Ti, no reflections can be observed, except for a small peak at ca. 25°, which is attributed to the (101) lattice plane of anatase TiO2. The ionic radii of Sn4+ (0.071nm) and Ti4+ (0.068nm) are so similar that Sn4+ can incorporate into the anatase TiO2 lattice to easily form a SnMnTiO x solid solution [30]. These very low intensity reflections confirm that the addition of Sn can significantly decrease the crystallinity of the samples [30]. To investigate whether the physical structures of the catalysts change during the catalytic reaction, several characterization methods, including XRD, Raman spectroscopy and N2 adsorption–desorption (the results of the N2 adsorption–desorption measurements are summarized in Table 1 ), for the fresh and used catalysts (used catalysts refer to the most poisoned catalysts, which are reacted at 175°C for 100h, denoted as used Mn–Ti or Sn–Mn–Ti in the later text) were employed. The results indicate that the aforementioned parameters minimally changed after the oxidation of CB for both the Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts, indicating that the physical structures of catalysts do not change during the stability test. Raman spectroscopy is a powerful experimental technique for probing the structural properties of materials. The room temperature Raman spectra of the as-obtained samples are shown in Fig. 5 . The spectrum of fresh TiO2 shows five peaks centered at 151, 201, 399, 519 and 644cm−1, which are attributed to typical anatase TiO2. The Raman spectra of fresh Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti are similar to that of TiO2, and no characteristic vibrational modes of MnO or SnO are observed. This result is because the MnO stretching mode occurs at ca. 390cm−1, the MnO bending modes lie in the region from 500 to 700cm−1 [31], the characteristic peak of SnO are centered at 470cm−1, 630cm−1 and 771cm−1 [32], and these Raman peaks overlap with the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 to form three broad peaks in the region 250–900cm−1. Moreover, although the XRD pattern of Sn–Mn–Ti does not show any appreciable peaks, the Raman spectrum clearly exhibits peaks attributed to anatase TiO2, indicating that the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst exits in the form of TiO2 minicrystals and that manganese and tin ions enter the anatase TiO2 lattice to form SnMnTiO x solid solution. Furthermore, the SAED patterns (Fig. 6 ) also demonstrate that the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst exits as anatase TiO2, not as an amorphous form as indicated by the XRD results. To gain better insight into the nature of the species and the surface groups of the catalysts, the catalysts were examined using XPS (see Fig. 7 ), and the data are summarized in Table 1. The Mn 2p profile could be deconvoluted into three contributions referred to Mn2+ at ca. 640.5eV, Mn3+ at ca. 641.8eV and Mn4+ at ca. 643.7eV [20], respectively. From Table 1, it can be seen that the average valence (that is, the average oxidation state, denoted as AOS) of the Mn species for Mn–Ti catalyst deceases after the stability test. However, this situation does not occur for the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst and the AOS for both the fresh and used Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts are less than that of the fresh Mn–Ti catalyst. A similar trend is observed in the O 1s XPS spectra. As shown in Fig. 7(B), the O 1s profile can be deconvoluted into three contributions: the lattice oxygen (denoted as Olatt) at 529.4–530eV, the surface-adsorbed oxygen (i.e., O2 2− or O−, hydroxyl OH− and carbonate CO3 2−, denoted as Oads) at 531–531.7eV and adsorbed molecular water (denoted as Owat) at 532.7eV [20]. For Mn–Ti, the intensity of the Oads peak weakens following the stability test, whereas the intensities of all kinds of oxygen species remain nearly constant for the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst after the oxidation of CB. In addition, for fresh Sn–Mn–Ti, the intensity of the Oads peak is weaker than that of the fresh Mn–Ti sample. The above results indicate that the addition of Sn decreases the AOS and the content of the surface-adsorbed oxygen. The Sn 3d XPS spectra are presented in Fig. 7(C). Notably, the intensity of Sn2+ peak (485.2eV) increases after stability test, revealing that some Sn4+ participates in the catalytic oxidation process and is reduced to Sn2+. The Cl 2p spectra are presented in Fig. 7(D). Cl species is not detected for fresh Mn–Ti and its content reached 1.02% after 100h running. As for Sn–Mn–Ti, the surface Cl content of fresh and used samples were 0.31% and 0.82%. The pristine Cl of fresh Sn–Mn–Ti is attributed to precursor SnCl2·2H2O and it is very difficult to wash off Cl ion completely. The final Cl content of used Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti indicated that the addition of Sn can improve the resistance to Cl poisoning for Mn–Ti catalyst. From Table 1, the actual molar ratio of Sn/Sn+Mn+Ti is considerably higher than its theoretical value, indicating that the surface segregation effect of Sn is significant. This phenomenon occurs because the ionic radius of Sn4+ (0.071nm) is larger than that of Ti4+ (0.068nm), and ions with larger size are likely to be present on the surface during the preparation of samples. Fig. 8 presents the H2-TPR results of the Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts. The fresh Mn–Ti catalyst shows two distinct peaks, which are attributed to the successive reduction of MnO2/Mn2O3 →Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 →MnO [33]. For Mn–Ti(175°C), Mn–Ti(225°C) and Mn–Ti(250°C), the reduction peaks shift to higher temperature regions with maximums at approximately 350°C and 500°C, respectively. Compared with fresh Mn–Ti, the intensity of the low temperature reduction peaks for these used catalysts decreases, indicating that the content of high-valence Mn deceases after the oxidation of CB, which is consistent with the XPS results. In addition, a new shoulder peak centered at approximately 300°C is observed, which can be attributed to the removal of Cl species adsorbed on the surface of Mn (denoted as ClMn), that is, H2 reacts with adsorbed Cl to form HCl. For Mn–Ti(300°C), high temperature and adequate O2 promoted the activation of catalyst to some extent, and the reduction temperatures of Mn shift to lower values, resulting in the shoulder peak and low temperature reduction peak overlapping and forming a broad peak that ranges from 200°C to 410°C. Furthermore, for the used catalysts, a new broad peak centered in the region of 700–800°C appears, especially for Mn–Ti(250°C) and Mn–Ti(300°C), which is attributed to the reduction of oxychlorinated manganese (MnO x Cl y ) [3,34]. This peak appears because the absorbed Cl species react with surface Mn to form MnO x Cl y at high temperature (greater than 250°C). For fresh Sn–Mn–Ti, the reduction temperatures of Mn shift to a higher range with two peaks located at 345°C and 488°C, implying that the addition of Sn increases the difficulty of reducing the Mn species, which is consistent with the results of Corradini et al. [35]. On the other hand, the TPR peaks corresponding to the Mn species are less intense compared with those of fresh Mn–Ti, indicating that Mn exists mainly in low valence state, which is in agreement with the XPS results. Furthermore, the TPR profile of fresh Sn–Mn–Ti shows a significant reduction peak with a maximum at approximately 565°C, which is attributed to the reduction of SnO2. This peak occurs because the temperatures for the reduction of Sn4+ →Sn2+ (at ca. 540°C) and Sn2+ →Sn0 (at ca. 590°C) [36,37] are so similar that only one overlapped peak can be observed. For the used samples, the TPR reduction peaks of the Mn species follow an almost similar pattern as those for the fresh Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst; however, the reduction of Sn2+ →Sn0 consumes more H2, which result in the Sn2+ →Sn0 reduction peak being more intense. This phenomenon indicates that Sn species participate in the catalytic reaction and that some Sn4+ is reduced to Sn2+. Similar to the used Mn–Ti catalysts, the peak centered at ca. 300°C is attributed to ClMn. Furthermore, a new shoulder peak centered at 220°C appears. It is reasonable to infer that the shoulder peak is attributed to the reduction of Cl species that are adsorbed on the surface of Sn (denoted as ClSn). In addition, no reduction peaks are observed in the region of 700–800°C for the used Sn–Mn–Ti catalysts, indicating that the addition of Sn can inhibit the formation of MnO x Cl y . In the catalytic oxidation of CB, Cl can easily separate from CB through nucleophilic reaction [38,39], and Cl species can easily adsorb on the metal cation (i.e., Mn X+ or Sn X+). However, the desorption of Cl species is considerably more difficult. From the TPR results reveal that the reduction temperature of ClSn is lower than that of ClMn, indicating that the desorption of ClSn consumes less energy than that of ClMn. In other words, the addition of Sn decreases the average energy that is required to desorb Cl species. On the other hand, the addition of Sn inhibits the formation of MnO x Cl y , which is beneficial for reducing the difficulty of removing Cl species. These two aspects are why the addition of Sn can enhance the resistance of Mn–Ti catalysts to chlorine poisoning. 4 Conclusion MnO X –TiO2 and SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts were prepared using homogeneous precipitation method and evaluated for the catalytic oxidation for chlorobenzene (CB). The activity tests revealed that both Mn–Ti and Sn–Mn–Ti mixed-oxide catalysts exhibit high activity for the low-temperature catalytic degradation of CB, whereas the SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 samples showed significantly higher stabilities than that of the MnO x –TiO2 catalyst. At 225°C, Sn–Mn–Ti presents more stable activity with a CB conversion of greater than 97% during the 100h reaction than all reported catalysts for CB oxidation, revealing that the addition of Sn could remarkably improve the stability of Mn–Ti catalysts for the oxidation of chlorobenzene. The characterization results revealed that the enhanced stability of the SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 samples can be attributed to the fact the introduction of Sn could inhibit the formation of MnO x Cl y and decrease the average energy required to remove chlorine species. Therefore, SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts will become useful in improving catalytic stability for the abatement of CVOCs. coredata.dc:description: In this study, MnO x –TiO2 and SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts were prepared using a homogeneous precipitation method and were investigated for the catalytic combustion of chlorobenzene (CB), which was used as a model compound of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs). The catalytic activity tests revealed that both catalysts exhibited an outstanding activity in catalytic degradation of CB, with 90% conversion occurring below 180°C. A significantly higher stability was observed for the Sn–Mn–Ti catalyst compared with Mn–Ti samples, revealing that the stability of Mn–Ti catalysts for the oxidation of chlorobenzene could be remarkably improved via the introduction of Sn. The obtained catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, N2 physisorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron (XPS) and hydrogen temperature-programed reduction (H2-TPR). Characterization of the catalysts indicated that the enhanced catalytic stability of the SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts was related to the lower average energy required to desorb Cl species and to the absence of MnO x Cl y on the active sites during the reaction, which remarkably improved the thermal stability of catalyst. Hence, SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts are a potential material for the abatement of CVOCs.
coredata.dc:title: SnO x –MnO x –TiO2 catalysts with high resistance to chlorine poisoning for low-temperature chlorobenzene oxidation
